bioghist.p: John Fryer (1938-2003) was a groundbreaking gay psychiatrist who is best-known for appearing in full disguise at the 1972 meeting of the American Psychiatric Association as "Dr. H. Anonymous." This performance is credited with convincing the APA's Board to remove homosexuality from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders in 1973. Dr. Fryer, who was born in Kentucky, moved to Germantown in 1972. He was initially active in the community and continued to play the organ at his Episcopal Church. He loved to travel, especially to London, Switzerland, and St. Lucia. In his professional life, Fryer worked largely with gays, lesbians, people who abused alcohol and drugs, and those who were coping with death and dying.

scopecontent.p: This large collection is comprised of the personal and professional papers of John Fryer. The papers span from Fryer's teens to the last months of his life. There are personal and professional correspondence files; subject files; patient files; student papers from Transylvania and Vanderbilt Universities, notebooks, and exam books; appointment books; diplomas and certificates; and personal and travel diaries. There are materials related to courses taught by Fryer at Temple University Medical School, including syllabi, student records, and reference materials. Reference materials and manuscripts related to Fryer's research on the connections between religion and health, on death and dying, community mental health, cancer care, and on persons living with AIDS/HIV, including a manuscript of a book co-edited by Fryer on care of persons living with AIDS/HIV. Materials related to Fryer's role as member of and organist for St. Peters, including music, church bulletins and programs, notes for meditations, periodicals, and a collection of old bulletins from St. Peter's (1897-1915). There are many photographs and slides, some ephemera, organ music, and several videos and cassettes featuring Dr. Fryer and other psychiatrists and medical professionals.
